column1: |488 u.s. 1301|"Baltimore Department of Social Services v. Bouknight

An application to stay the judgment of the Court of Appeals of Maryland -- that Jacqueline Bouknight's confinement for civil contempt violated her privilege against self-incrimination under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution -- is granted pending the timely filing and subsequent disposition of a petition for certiorari.  At the request of the Baltimore City Department of Social Services (DSS)
column2: the circuit court for the city determined that Bouknight's son
column3: Maurice
column4: who had received several suspicious injuries
column5: was a ""child in need of assistance"" under Maryland law.  Bouknight received supervised custody of Maurice
column6: but failed to cooperate with DSS and refused to produce him or tell DSS where he was.  Subsequently
column7: she was arrested and ordered to disclose the child's whereabouts.  After giving a false answer
column8: she was jailed until she purged herself of contempt by either producing Maurice or revealing his location.  The Court of Appeals found that the terms of the confinement violated Bouknight's privilege against self-incrimination
column9: since the risk that producing Maurice would necessarily admit a measure of continuing control over the child that might be relevant in a subsequent criminal prosecution could not be outweighed by any governmental interest in finding Maurice.  DSS meets the requirements for the issuance of a stay.  The lower court's decision is based on the United States Constitution
column10: and the burden on Bouknight's liberty must be weighed against the very real jeopardy to a child's safety and wellbeing
column11: and perhaps even his life.  If Bouknight is permitted to go free
column12: DSS may not have the means to obtain information about or to locate the child.  Also
column13: it is likely that four Justices will vote to grant certiorari
column14: and DSS has a fair prospect of persuading a majority of the Court that the state court decision was erroneous.

column1: 1. Statements in the form of opinions or conclusions are not by that fact excluded from the scope of Rule 803(8)(C).  The Rule's language does not call for the distinction between ""fact"" and ""opinion"" drawn by Smith

column3: and other proponents of a narrow interpretation of the Rule's ""factual findings"" phrase
column4: since ""finding of fact"" is commonly defined to include conclusions by way of reasonable inference from the evidence

column2: an unincorporated association consisting of approximately 960 public and private universities and colleges
column3: adopts rules governing member institutions' recruiting
column4: admissions
column5: academic eligibility
column6: and financial aid standards for student athletes.  The NCAA's Committee on Infractions conducts investigations
column7: makes factual determinations
column8: and is expressly authorized to impose penalties upon members that have violated the rules
column9: but is not authorized to sanction a member institution's employees directly.  After a lengthy investigation of allegedly improper recruiting practices by the University of Nevada
column10: Las Vegas (UNLV)
column11: a state university
column14: UNLV's basketball coach.  The Committee imposed a number of sanctions upon UNLV
column15: and requested it to show cause why additional penalties should not be imposed if it failed to suspend Tarkanian from its athletic program during a probation period.  Facing demotion and a drastic cut in pay
column16: Tarkanian brought suit in Nevada state court
column17: alleging that he had been deprived of his Fourteenth Amendment due process rights in violation of 42 U.S.C.  1983.  Ultimately
column18: Tarkanian obtained injunctive relief and an award of attorney's fees against both UNLV and the NCAA.  Concluding that the NCAA's conduct constituted state action for jurisdictional and constitutional purposes
column19: the Nevada Supreme Court affirmed in relevant part.

column1: Held:  The NCAA's participation in the events that led to Tarkanian's suspension did not constitute ""state action"" prohibited by the Fourteenth Amendment
column2: and was not performed ""under color of "" state law within the meaning of  1983.  The NCAA cannot be deemed to be a state actor on the theory that it misused power it possessed by virtue of state law
column3: since UNLV's decision to suspend Tarkanian
column4: while in compliance with the NCAA's rules and recommendations
column5: did not turn the NCAA's conduct into action under color of Nevada law.  Although it must be assumed that UNLV
column6: as an NCAA member and a participant in the promulgation of the Association's rules
column7: had some minor impact on the NCAA's policy determinations
column8: the source of the rules adopted by the NCAA is not Nevada
column9: but the collective membership
column10: the vast majority of which was located in other States.  Moreover
column11: UNLV's decision to

column1: adopt the NCAA's rules did not transform them into state rules
column2: and the NCAA into a state actor
column3: since UNLV retained plenary power to withdraw from the NCAA and to establish its own standards.  The NCAA's investigation
column4: enforcement proceedings
column5: and consequent recommendations did not constitute state action on the theory that they resulted from a delegation of power by UNLV
column6: because:  UNLV delegated no power to the NCAA to take specific action against any University employee; UNLV and the NCAA acted as adversaries throughout the proceedings; the NCAA enjoyed no governmental powers to facilitate its investigation; and the NCAA did not -- indeed
column7: could not -- directly discipline Tarkanian
column8: but could only threaten additional sanctions against UNLV if the University chose not to suspend its coach.  Furthermore
column9: even assuming the truth of Tarkanian's argument that the power of the NCAA is so great that UNLV had no practical alternative but to comply with the Association's demands
column10: it does not follow that the NCAA was therefore acting under color of state law.  Pp.  488 U. S. 191-199.

column1: 1. An administrative agency's power to promulgate regulations is limited to the authority delegated by Congress.  As a general matter

column2: a 10-year-old boy
column3: was molested and sodomized by a middle-aged man for 1 1/2 hours.  After the assault
column4: the boy was taken to a hospital
column5: where a physician used a swab from a ""sexual assault kit"" to collect semen samples from the boy's rectum.  The police also collected the boy's clothing
column6: which they failed to refrigerate.  A police criminologist later performed some tests on the rectal swab and the boy's clothing
column7: but he was unable to obtain information about the identity of the boy's assailant.  At trial
column8: expert witnesses testified that respondent might have been completely exonerated by timely performance of tests on properly preserved semen samples.  Respondent was convicted of child molestation
column9: sexual assault
column10: and kidnaping in an Arizona state court.  The Arizona Court of Appeals reversed the conviction on the ground that the State had breached a constitutional duty to preserve the semen samples from the victim's body and clothing.

column1: Held:  The Due Process Clause did not require the State to preserve the semen samples even though the samples might have been useful to respondent.  Unless a criminal defendant can show bad faith on the part of the police
column2: failure to preserve potentially useful evidence does not constitute a denial of due process of law.  Here
column3: the police's failure to refrigerate the victim's clothing and to perform tests on the semen samples can at worst be described as negligent.  None of this information was concealed from respondent at trial
column4: and the evidence -- such as it was -- was made available to respondent's expert
column5: who declined to perform any tests on the samples.  The Arizona Court of Appeals noted in its opinion -- and this Court agrees -- that there was no suggestion of bad faith on the part of the police.  Moreover
column6: the Due Process Clause was not violated because the State failed to perform a newer test on the semen samples.  The police do not have a constitutional duty to perform any particular tests.  Pp.  488 U. S. 55-59.

column4: that he had found no errors requiring reversal
column5: and that he would not file a meritless appeal
column6: and which requested leave to withdraw.  The court entered an order that granted the latter motion and that specified that the court would thereafter independently review the record thoroughly to determine whether any reversible error existed.  The court later denied petitioner's request for the appointment of a new attorney.  Subsequently
column7: upon making its own examination of the record without the assistance of counsel for petitioner
column8: the court noted that counsel's certification of meritlessness was ""highly questionable
column9: since petitioner had ""several arguable claims
column10: and
column11: in fact
column12: reversed one of petitioner's convictions for plain error
column13: but concluded that petitioner ""suffered no prejudice"" as a result of ""counsel's failure to give a more conscientious examination of the record"" because the court had thoroughly examined the record and received the benefit of arguments advanced by the codefendants' counsel.  The court therefore affirmed petitioner's convictions on the remaining counts
column14: and the State Supreme Court dismissed his appeal.

column1: 1. Petitioner was deprived of constitutionally adequate representation on appeal by the Ohio Court of Appeals' failure to follow the procedures set forth in Anders v. California
column3: for allowing appointed counsel for an indigent criminal defendant to withdraw from a first appeal as of right on the basis that the appeal is frivolous.  Under those procedures
column4: counsel must first conduct a ""conscientious examination"" of the case and support a request to withdraw with a brief referring to anything in the record that might arguably support the appeal
column5: and the court must then conduct a full examination of all the proceedings and permit withdrawal if its separate inquiry reveals no nonfrivolous issue
column6: but must appoint new counsel to argue the appeal if such an issue exists.  The state court erred in two respects in not denying counsel's motion to withdraw.  First
column7: the motion was not supported with an ""Anders brief

column1: that the court was left without an adequate basis for determining that counsel had performed his duty of carefully searching the record for arguable error
column2: and was deprived of assistance in the court's own review of the record.  Second
column3: the court should not have acted on the motion before it made its own examination of the record to determine whether counsel's evaluation of the case was sound.  Most significantly
column4: the court erred by failing to appoint new counsel to represent petitioner after determining that the record supported ""several arguable claims.""  Such a determination creates a constitutional imperative that counsel be appointed
column5: since the need for forceful and vigorous advocacy to ensure that rights are not forgone and that substantial legal and factual arguments are not passed over is of paramount importance in our adversary system of justice
column6: whether at the trial or the appellate stage.  Pp.  488 U. S. 79-85.

column2: it is inappropriate to apply either the lack of prejudice standard of Strickland v. Washington
column4: or the harmless error analysis of Chapman v. California
column5: 386 U. S. 18.  Such application would render the protections afforded by Anders meaningless
column6: since the appellant would suffer no prejudice or harm from the denial of counsel
column7: and would thus have no basis for complaint
column9: on reviewing the bare appellate record
column10: concluded either that the conviction should not be reversed or that there was a basis for reversal.  The Court of Appeals' consideration of the appellate briefs filed on behalf of petitioner's codefendants does not alter this conclusion
column11: since a criminal appellant is entitled to a single-minded advocacy for which the mere possibility of a coincidence of interest with a represented codefendant is an inadequate proxy.  More significantly
column12: the question whether the briefs filed by the codefendants
column13: along with the court's own review of the record
column14: adequately focused the court's attention on petitioner's arguable claims is itself an issue that should have been resolved in an adversary proceeding.  Furthermore
column15: it is important that the denial of counsel in this case left petitioner completely without representation during the appellate court's actual decisional process
column16: since such a total denial is legally presumed to result in prejudice
column17: and can never be considered harmless error
column18: whether at the trial or the appellate stage.  Pp.  488 U. S. 85-89.

column1: Arkansas' habitual criminal statute provides that a defendant who is convicted of a class B felony may be sentenced to an enhanced term of imprisonment if the State proves beyond a reasonable doubt
column2: at a separate sentencing hearing
column3: that he has at least four prior felony convictions.  At respondent's sentencing hearing following his guilty plea to a class B felony
column4: the State introduced certified copies of four prior felony convictions
column5: one of which
column6: unbeknownst to the prosecutor
column7: had been pardoned by the Governor.  The case was submitted to the jury
column8: which found that the State had met its burden of proving four prior felony convictions and imposed an enhanced sentence.  Several years later
column9: respondent sought a writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court
column10: contending that the enhanced sentence was invalid because one of the convictions used to support it had been pardoned.  The District Court determined that the conviction in question had in fact been pardoned
column11: and set aside the enhanced sentence.  The District Court then held
column12: in reliance on Burks v. United States
column14: that the Double Jeopardy Clause prohibited the State from attempting to resentence respondent as a habitual offender on the basis of another prior conviction not offered or admitted at the initial sentencing hearing.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column15: reasoning that the pardoned conviction was inadmissible under state law
column16: and that the Double Jeopardy Clause forbade retrial because the remaining evidence adduced at trial was legally insufficient to sustain the jury's verdict of enhancement.

column1: Held:  When a reviewing court determines that a defendant's conviction must be set aside because certain evidence was erroneously admitted against him
column2: and further finds that
column3: once that evidence is discounted
column4: there is insufficient evidence to support the conviction
column5: the Double Jeopardy Clause does not forbid his retrial so long as the sum of the evidence offered by the State and admitted by the trial court -- whether erroneously or not -- would have been sufficient to sustain a guilty verdict.  The general rule is that the Double Jeopardy Clause does not preclude the retrial of a defendant who succeeds in getting his conviction set aside for such ""trial errors"" as the incorrect receipt or rejection of evidence.  The Burks exception to that rule is based on the view that a reversal for

column1: evidentiary insufficiency is the functional equivalent of a trial court's granting a judgment of acquittal at the close of all the evidence.  Because a trial court
column2: in passing on such a motion
column3: considers all of the evidence it has admitted
column4: it must be this same quantum of evidence which is considered in deciding whether retrial is permissible under the Double Jeopardy Clause.  Permitting retrial in this instance is not the sort of oppression at which the Double Jeopardy Clause is aimed
column5: but simply affords the defendant an opportunity to obtain a fair adjudication of his guilt free from error.  Pp.  488 U. S. 38-42.

column2: a portion of Shell Oil Company's gross revenues was derived from the sale of oil and natural gas extracted from the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS).  Shell sold all of its OCS gas directly at the OCS wellhead platform
column3: but piped most of its OCS crude oil inland
column4: where it was either sold to third parties or refined
column5: which typically involved commingling it with non-OCS oil.  Shell's principal business in Iowa during the years at issue was the sale of oil and chemical products which were manufactured and refined elsewhere and included commingled OCS oil.  In computing its Iowa corporate income taxes for those years
column6: Shell adjusted the apportionment formula the State uses to calculate in-state taxable income -- under which that portion of overall net income that is ""reasonably attributable to the trade or business within the state"" is taxed -- to exclude a figure which Shell claimed reflected income earned from the OCS.  The Iowa formula had previously been upheld against Due Process and Commerce Clause challenges in Moorman Mfg. Co. v. Bair
column7: 437 U. S. 267.  The Iowa Department of Revenue rejected Shell's modification of the formula and found the tax payments deficient
column8: which decision was affirmed by a county district court and by the Iowa Supreme Court.  Both courts rejected Shell's contention that the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act (OCSLA) preempts Iowa's apportionment formula
column9: and therefore prevents the State from taxing income earned from the sale of OCS oil and gas.

column1: Held:  The OCSLA does not prevent Iowa from including income earned from the sale of OCS oil and gas in its apportionment formula.  In adopting for the OCS the civil and criminal laws of ""each adjacent state
column2: the OCSLA does provide that ""[s]tate taxation laws shall not apply"" and further specifies that such adoption ""shall never be interpreted as a basis for [a State's] claiming any interest in [the OCS] or the revenues therefrom.""  However
column3: the above-quoted provisions
column4: when read in the context of the entire section in which they appear
column5: and the background and legislative history of the OCSLA
column6: establish that Congress was exclusively concerned with preventing adjacent States from asserting
column7: on the basis of territorial claims
column8: jurisdiction to assess on the OCS those direct taxes commonly imposed by States adjacent to offshore production sites
column9: and did not intend to prohibit a State from taxing income from OCS-derived oil and gas
column10: provided that it does so pursuant to a constitutionally

column1: permissible apportionment scheme such as Iowa's.  The inclusion of OCS-derived income in the unitary tax base of such a formula does not amount to extraterritorial taxation prohibited by the OCSLA.  Shell's argument that
column2: even if the OCSLA allows a State to include in its preapportioned tax base the sales of OCS crude oil which occur off the OCS
column3: the taxing State may not include in that base the value of the natural gas sales made at the OCS wellhead is rejected
column4: since
column5: on its face
column6: the OCSLA makes no such distinction
column7: and
column9: it is irrelevant for the makeup of the apportionment formula's unitary tax base that third-party sales occur outside of the State.  Pp.  488 U. S. 24-31.

The North Carolina Charitable Solicitations Act defines the prima facie ""reasonable fee"" that a professional fundraiser may charge according to a three-tiered schedule. column1: While surveiling petitioner Murray and others suspected of illegal drug activities
column2: federal agents observed both petitioners driving vehicles into
column3: and later out of
column4: a warehouse
column5: and
column6: upon petitioners' exit
column7: saw that the warehouse contained a tractor-trailer rig bearing a long container.  Petitioners later turned over their vehicles to other drivers
column8: who were in turn followed and ultimately arrested
column9: and the vehicles were lawfully seized and found to contain marijuana.  After receiving this information
column10: several agents forced their way into the warehouse and observed in plain view numerous burlap-wrapped bales.  The agents left without disturbing the bales and did not return until they had obtained a warrant to search the warehouse.  In applying for the warrant
column11: they did not mention the prior entry or include any recitations of their observations made during that entry.  Upon issuance of the warrant
column12: they reentered the warehouse and seized 270 bales of marijuana and other evidence of crime.  The District Court denied petitioners' pretrial motion to suppress the evidence
column13: rejecting their arguments that the warrant was invalid because the agents did not inform the Magistrate about their prior warrantless entry
column14: and that the warrant was tainted by that entry.  Petitioners were subsequently convicted of conspiracy to possess and distribute illegal drugs.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column15: assuming for purposes of its decision on the suppression question that the first entry into the warehouse was unlawful.

column1: Held:  The Fourth Amendment does not require the suppression of evidence initially discovered during police officers' illegal entry of private premises if that evidence is also discovered during a later search pursuant to a valid warrant that is wholly independent of the initial illegal entry.  Pp.  487 U. S. 536-544.
(a) The ""independent source"" doctrine permits the introduction of evidence initially discovered during
column2: or as a consequence of
column3: an unlawful search
column4: but later obtained independently from lawful activities untainted by the initial illegality.  Silverthorne Lumber Co. v. United States
column5: 251 U. S. 385.  There is no merit to petitioners' contention that allowing the

column1: doctrine to apply to evidence initially discovered during an illegal search
column2: rather than limiting it to evidence first obtained during a later lawful search
column3: will encourage police routinely to enter premises without a warrant.  Pp.  487 U. S. 536-541.

column1: (b) Although the federal agents' knowledge that marijuana was in the warehouse was assuredly acquired at the time of the unlawful entry
column2: it was also acquired at the time of entry pursuant to the warrant
column3: and if that later acquisition was not the result of the earlier entry
column4: the independent source doctrine allows the admission of testimony as to that knowledge.  This same analysis applies to the tangible evidence
column5: the bales of marijuana.  United States v. Silvestri
column7: is unpersuasive insofar as it distinguishes between tainted intangible and tangible evidence.  The ultimate question is whether the search pursuant to warrant was in fact a genuinely independent source of the information and tangible evidence at issue.  This would not have been the case if the agents' decision to seek the warrant was prompted by what they had seen during the initial entry or if information obtained during that entry was presented to the Magistrate and affected his decision to issue the warrant.  Because the District Court did not explicitly find that the agents would have sought a warrant if they had not earlier entered the warehouse
column8: the cases are remanded for a determination whether the warrant-authorized search of the warehouse was an independent source in the sense herein described.  Pp.  487 U. S. 541-544.

column1: One of petitioner's predecessors as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development decided not to implement an ""operating subsidy"" program authorized by federal statute
column2: which was intended to provide payments to owners of Government-subsidized apartment buildings to offset rising utility expenses and property taxes.  Various plaintiffs
column3: including respondent members of a nationwide class of Government-subsidized housing tenants
column4: successfully challenged the decision in lawsuits in nine Federal District Courts.  After two of the decisions were affirmed by Courts of Appeals
column5: a newly appointed Secretary settled with most of the plaintiffs
column6: including respondents.  While the District Court was administering the settlement
column7: Congress passed the Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA)
column8: which authorizes an award of reasonable attorney's fees against the Government ""unless the court finds that the position of the United States was substantially justified.""  Under the EAJA
column9: the amount of fees awarded must

column1: be based upon prevailing market rates for the kind and quality of the services furnished
column2: except that . . . fees shall not be awarded in excess of $75 per hour unless the court determines that an increase in the cost of living or a special factor
column3: such as the limited availability of qualified attorneys for the proceedings involved
column4: justifies a higher fee.""

column1: The court awarded fees to respondents under the EAJA
column2: concluding that the decision not to implement the operating subsidy program had not been ""substantially justified
column3: and basing the amount of the award
column4: which exceeded $1 million
column5: on ""special factors"" justifying hourly rates in excess of the $75 cap.  The Court of Appeals held that the District Court had not abused its discretion in concluding that the Secretary's position was not substantially justified
column6: and that the special factors relied on by the District Court justified exceeding the $75 cap.

column1: 1. In reviewing the District Court's determination that the Secretary's position was not ""substantially justified
column2: the Court of Appeals correctly applied an abuse-of-discretion standard
column3: rather than a de novo standard of review.  Neither a clear statutory prescription nor a historical tradition requires this choice of standards.  However
column4: deferential
column5: abuse-of-discretion review is suggested by the EAJA's language
column6: which

column1: requires a fees award ""unless the court finds that"" (rather than simply ""unless"") the United States' position was substantially justified
column2: and by the statute's structure
column3: which expressly provides an abuse-of-discretion standard for review of agency fee determinations.  As a matter of sound judicial administration
column4: the district courts are in a better position than the courts of appeals to decide the substantial justification question.  Moreover
column5: that question is multifarious
column6: novel
column7: and little susceptible of useful generalization at this time
column8: and is therefore likely to profit from the experience that an abuse-of-discretion standard will permit to develop.  Pp.  487 U. S. 557-563.

column1: 2. The statutory phrase ""substantially justified"" means justified in substance
column2: or in the main -- that is
column3: justified to a degree that could satisfy a reasonable person.  This interpretation of the phrase accords with related uses of the term ""substantial
column4: and is equivalent to the ""reasonable basis both in law and fact"" formulation adopted by the vast majority of Courts of Appeals.  Respondents' reliance on a House Committee Report pertaining to the 1985 reenactment of the EAJA for the proposition that ""substantial justification"" means ""more than mere reasonableness"" is misplaced
column5: since the 1985 Report is not an authoritative interpretation of what the 1980 statute meant or of language drafted by the 1985 Committee
column6: which merely accepted the existing statutory phrase.  Pp.  487 U. S. 563-568.

column1: 3. The Court of Appeals correctly ruled that the District Court did not abuse its discretion in finding that the Government's position was not ""substantially justified.""  Although ""objective indicia"" can be relevant to establishing ""substantial justification
column2: they are inconclusive in this case.  The Government's willingness to settle the litigation and the stage in the proceedings at which the merits were decided are not reliable objective indicia here.  Neither are views expressed by other courts on the merits
column3: which provide some support on both sides.  The Government's arguments on the merits of the underlying issue do not command the conclusion that its position was substantially justified.  Pp.  487 U. S. 568-571.

column1: 4. The District Court abused its discretion in fixing the amount of respondents' attorney's fees
column2: since none of the reasons relied on by the court to increase the reimbursement rate above the statutory maximum was a ""special factor"" within the EAJA's meaning.  Since the ""special factor"" formulation suggests that Congress thought that $75 an hour is generally sufficient regardless of the prevailing market rate
column3: the ""limited availability"" factor must refer to attorneys ""qualified for the proceedings"" in some specialized sense
column4: such as patent lawyers for patent proceedings
column5: rather than just in their general legal competence.  Similarly
column6: in order to preserve the $75 cap's effectiveness
column7: other ""special factors""

column1: must be such as are not of broad and general application.  Thus
column2: most of the factors relied on by the court -- the ""novelty and difficulty of issues
column3: ""the undesirability of the case
column4: ""the work and ability of counsel
column5: ""the results obtained
column6: and ""the contingent nature of the fee"" -- do not qualify
column7: since they are applicable to a broad spectrum of litigation

column1: One of petitioner's predecessors as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development decided not to implement an ""operating subsidy"" program authorized by federal statute
column2: which was intended to provide payments to owners of Government-subsidized apartment buildings to offset rising utility expenses and property taxes.  Various plaintiffs
column3: including respondent members of a nationwide class of Government-subsidized housing tenants
column4: successfully challenged the decision in lawsuits in nine Federal District Courts.  After two of the decisions were affirmed by Courts of Appeals
column5: a newly appointed Secretary settled with most of the plaintiffs
column6: including respondents.  While the District Court was administering the settlement
column7: Congress passed the Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA)
column8: which authorizes an award of reasonable attorney's fees against the Government ""unless the court finds that the position of the United States was substantially justified.""  Under the EAJA
column9: the amount of fees awarded must

column1: be based upon prevailing market rates for the kind and quality of the services furnished
column2: except that . . . fees shall not be awarded in excess of $75 per hour unless the court determines that an increase in the cost of living or a special factor
column3: such as the limited availability of qualified attorneys for the proceedings involved
column4: justifies a higher fee.""

column1: The court awarded fees to respondents under the EAJA
column2: concluding that the decision not to implement the operating subsidy program had not been ""substantially justified
column3: and basing the amount of the award
column4: which exceeded $1 million
column5: on ""special factors"" justifying hourly rates in excess of the $75 cap.  The Court of Appeals held that the District Court had not abused its discretion in concluding that the Secretary's position was not substantially justified
column6: and that the special factors relied on by the District Court justified exceeding the $75 cap.

column1: 1. In reviewing the District Court's determination that the Secretary's position was not ""substantially justified
column2: the Court of Appeals correctly applied an abuse-of-discretion standard
column3: rather than a de novo standard of review.  Neither a clear statutory prescription nor a historical tradition requires this choice of standards.  However
column4: deferential
column5: abuse-of-discretion review is suggested by the EAJA's language
column6: which

column1: requires a fees award ""unless the court finds that"" (rather than simply ""unless"") the United States' position was substantially justified
column2: and by the statute's structure
column3: which expressly provides an abuse-of-discretion standard for review of agency fee determinations.  As a matter of sound judicial administration
column4: the district courts are in a better position than the courts of appeals to decide the substantial justification question.  Moreover
column5: that question is multifarious
column6: novel
column7: and little susceptible of useful generalization at this time
column8: and is therefore likely to profit from the experience that an abuse-of-discretion standard will permit to develop.  Pp.  487 U. S. 557-563.

column1: 2. The statutory phrase ""substantially justified"" means justified in substance
column2: or in the main -- that is
column3: justified to a degree that could satisfy a reasonable person.  This interpretation of the phrase accords with related uses of the term ""substantial
column4: and is equivalent to the ""reasonable basis both in law and fact"" formulation adopted by the vast majority of Courts of Appeals.  Respondents' reliance on a House Committee Report pertaining to the 1985 reenactment of the EAJA for the proposition that ""substantial justification"" means ""more than mere reasonableness"" is misplaced
column5: since the 1985 Report is not an authoritative interpretation of what the 1980 statute meant or of language drafted by the 1985 Committee
column6: which merely accepted the existing statutory phrase.  Pp.  487 U. S. 563-568.

column1: 3. The Court of Appeals correctly ruled that the District Court did not abuse its discretion in finding that the Government's position was not ""substantially justified.""  Although ""objective indicia"" can be relevant to establishing ""substantial justification
column2: they are inconclusive in this case.  The Government's willingness to settle the litigation and the stage in the proceedings at which the merits were decided are not reliable objective indicia here.  Neither are views expressed by other courts on the merits
column3: which provide some support on both sides.  The Government's arguments on the merits of the underlying issue do not command the conclusion that its position was substantially justified.  Pp.  487 U. S. 568-571.

column1: 4. The District Court abused its discretion in fixing the amount of respondents' attorney's fees
column2: since none of the reasons relied on by the court to increase the reimbursement rate above the statutory maximum was a ""special factor"" within the EAJA's meaning.  Since the ""special factor"" formulation suggests that Congress thought that $75 an hour is generally sufficient regardless of the prevailing market rate
column3: the ""limited availability"" factor must refer to attorneys ""qualified for the proceedings"" in some specialized sense
column4: such as patent lawyers for patent proceedings
column5: rather than just in their general legal competence.  Similarly
column6: in order to preserve the $75 cap's effectiveness
column7: other ""special factors""

column1: must be such as are not of broad and general application.  Thus
column2: most of the factors relied on by the court -- the ""novelty and difficulty of issues
column3: ""the undesirability of the case
column4: ""the work and ability of counsel
column5: ""the results obtained
column6: and ""the contingent nature of the fee"" -- do not qualify
column7: since they are applicable to a broad spectrum of litigation
column8: and are little more than routine reasons why market rates are what they are.  Pennsylvania v. Delaware Valley Citizens' Council for Clean Air

column1: Edward SPANGLER v. UNITED STATES.No. 87-1643 Supreme Court of the United States June 27
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
The petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.

column2: dissenting.

column1: Petitioner was charged with several counts of extortion. At trial
column2: he testified in his own behalf and presented several witnesses who testified in support of his character and reputation. He requested that the jury be instructed that evidence of good reputation
column3: even standing alone
column4: may be sufficient to create a reasonable doubt about whether the defendant is guilty of the charges. Instead
column5: the jury was instructed to consider such character evidence along with all the other evidence presented in the case to determine whether the prosecution had proved beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant committed the particular crimes charged. The jury convicted petitioner
column6: and the Third Circuit affirmed
column7: holding that the trial judge did not abuse his discretion by refusing to give the requested instruction. 838 F.2d 85 (1988).

column1: The decision below adds to the considerable disagreement that has arisen in the Courts of Appeals about whether and when it is proper for the judge to give the ""standing alone"" instruction to the jury. Some courts have held that such an instruction is never necessary and often
column2: if not always
column3: is improper because it actually misleads the jury. See
column4: e.g.
column5: United States v. Burke
column7: 1238-1242 (CA7 1985); United States v. Winter
column9: 1146-1149 (CA1 1981); Black v. United States
column14: 83 S. Ct. 880 (1963). Other courts have disagreed with this view
column15: stating that at least in certain kinds of cases

column2: a defendant is entitled to have the jury be instructed that reputation evidence in and of itself can create a reasonable doubt as to guilt. See
column3: e.g.
column4: United States v. Lewis
column5: 157 U.S.App.D.C. 43
column7: 637 (1973); United States v. Cramer
column10: cert. denied
column11: 404 U.S. 1024 (1972). In addition
column12: many of the pattern jury instructions that have been used by District Courts around the country have included some kind of ""standing alone"" instruction. See
column19: n. 1 (CA5 1979). This confusion can be traced directly to statements made by this Court in Edgington v. United States
column23: and in Michelson v. United States
column26: 218 (1948). I would grant certiorari to resolve the longstanding division in the courts on this point.

column1: Rex H. REED v. Rosemary M. COLLYER etc. No. 87-1757 Supreme Court of the United States June 27
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
The petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.

column2: dissenting.

column1: This is a suit against the General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board
column2: alleging that in dismissing unfair labor practice charges filed by petitioner she violated petitioner's due process and equal protection rights under the Fifth Amendment. The District Court
column3: in an unpublished opinion
column4: dismissed the suit on the ground that the General Counsel's decision to dismiss was not subject to judicial review. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
column5: also in an unpublished opinion
column6: affirmed. Judgt. order reported at 837 F.2d 1091 ( 1988).

column1: While this petition for certiorari was pending
column2: this Court decided Webster v. Doe
column4: applying for the first time the principle that Congress' intent to preclude judicial review of ""constitutional claims"" must be expressed with greater clarity than its intent to preclude judicial review of other claims. Id.
column7: at ___. The statute that Webster found insufficiently clear for that purpose pertained to the Central Intelligence Agency
column8: and provided that ""[n]otwithstanding . . . the provisions of any other law
column9: the Director of Central Intelligence may
column10: in his discretion
column11: terminate the employment of any officer or employee of the Agency whenever he shall deem such termination necessary or advisable in the interests of the United States."" 50 U.S.C. 403(c). The statute at issue in the present case pertains to the NLRB
column12: and provides that the General Counsel ""shall have final authority
column14: in respect of the investigation of charges and issuance of complaints under section 160 of this title
column15: and in respect of the prosecution of such complaints before the Board. . . ."" 29 U.S.C. 153(d). The present case

column1: is unquestionably a prime candidate for application of the new principle we adopted in Webster. While the area of administrative activity to which the suit pertains (enforcement discretion) is one in which agencies have traditionally been accorded broad insulation from judicial review
column2: see Heckler v. Chaney
column4: so was the area of managing the Nation's intelligence services at issue in Webster. And the text of the statute in Webster was much more suggestive of total unreviewability.

column1: Petitioner has filed a supplemental brief persuasively arguing that Webster supports his position. Our denial of his petition is a puzzling departure from our standard practice of remanding (without opinion) pending cases whose outcome could well be affected by a decision we have promulgated after the judgment below. See R. Stern
column2: E. Gressman
column3: & S. Shapiro
column4: Supreme Court Practice 5.12
column5: p. 279 (6th ed. 1986). If we adhere to the rationale of Webster
column6: we should certainly grant this petition for certiorari
column7: vacate the judgment of the Sixth Circuit
column8: and remand this case for reconsideration in light of Webster. It was my view that the rationale of Webster was wrong
column9: because it did not square with the outcome of perfectly commonplace and perfectly correct decisions such as that of the Sixth Circuit here. See 486 U.S.
column10: at 606
column14: dissenting). I would grant certiorari in this case in order to begin the necessary process of limiting Webster to its facts.

column1: While incarcerated in a Tennessee prison

column4: 27 days after the judgment
column5: deposited the notice with the prison authorities for mailing to the District Court.  The date of deposit was recorded in the prison's outgoing mail log.  Because petitioner lacked the necessary funds
column6: prison authorities refused his requests to certify the notice for proof that it had been deposited for mailing on the day in question
column7: and to send the notice air mail.  Although the record contains no evidence of when the prison authorities actually mailed the notice or when the District Court actually received it

column6: unaided by counsel

The 30-day deadline for filing notices of appeal set forth in 28 U.S.C.  2107

column14: since the relevant question is one of timing
column16: and neither Rule sets forth criteria for determining the moment at which the filing has occurred.  The general rule that receipt by the court clerk constitutes filing

column1: After being informed by police that he had been indicted for murder
column2: petitioner
column3: who was in police custody
column4: twice indicated his willingness to discuss the crime during interviews initiated by the authorities.  On both occasions
column5: petitioner was read a form waiving his rights under Miranda v. Arizona
column7: initialed each of the five specific warnings on the form
column8: and signed the form.  He then gave inculpatory statements to the authorities.  The Illinois trial court denied his motions to suppress his statements on constitutional grounds
column9: and the statements were used against him at trial.  The State Supreme Court affirmed his conviction
column10: rejecting his contention that the warnings he received
column11: while adequate to protect his Fifth Amendment rights as guaranteed by Miranda
column12: did not adequately inform him of his Sixth Amendment right to counsel.

column1: Held:  The postindictment questioning that produced petitioner's incriminating statements did not violate his Sixth Amendment right to counsel.  Pp.  487 U. S. 290-300.
(a) Petitioner cannot avail himself of the argument that
column2: because his Sixth Amendment right to counsel arose with his indictment
column3: the police were thereafter barred from initiating questioning
column4: since he at no time sought to have counsel present.  The essence of Edwards v. Arizona
column6: and its progeny
column7: on which petitioner relies
column8: is the preservation of the integrity of an accused's choice to communicate with police only through counsel.  Had petitioner indicated he wanted counsel's assistance
column9: the questioning would have stopped
column10: and further questioning would have been forbidden unless he himself initiated the meeting.  Michigan v. Jackson
column11: 475 U. S. 625.  However
column12: once an accused ""knowingly and intelligently"" elects to proceed without counsel
column13: the uncounseled statements he then makes need not be excluded at trial.  Pp.  487 U. S. 290-291.

column1: (b) Petitioner's contention that his Sixth Amendment rights were violated because he did not ""knowingly and intelligently"" waive his right to have counsel present during his postindictment questioning is without merit.  The constitutional minimum for determining whether a waiver was ""knowing and intelligent"" is that the accused be made sufficiently aware of his right to have counsel present and of the possible consequences of a decision to forgo the aid of counsel.  Here
column2: by admonishing petitioner with the Miranda warnings
column3: respondent met this burden
column4: and petitioner's waiver was valid.  First
column5: by telling him that he had the

column2: to have a lawyer present while he was questioned
column3: and even to have a lawyer appointed if he could not afford one
column4: the authorities conveyed to him the sum and substance of his Sixth Amendment rights.  Second
column5: by informing him that any statement he made could be used against him
column6: the authorities made him aware of the ultimate adverse consequence of his decision to waive his Sixth Amendment rights
column7: and of what a lawyer could ""do for him"" during postindictment questioning:  namely
column8: advise him to refrain from making any such statements.  Petitioner's inability here to articulate with precision what additional information should have been provided before he would have been competent to waive his right to counsel supports the conclusion that the information that was provided satisfies the constitutional minimum.  Pp.  487 U. S. 292-297.

column1: (c) This Court has never adopted petitioner's suggestion that the Sixth Amendment right to counsel is ""superior"" to or ""more difficult"" to waive than its Fifth Amendment counterpart.  Rather
column2: in Sixth Amendment cases
column3: the court has defined the scope of the right to counsel by a pragmatic assessment of the usefulness of counsel to the accused at the particular stage of the proceedings in question
column4: and the dangers to the accused of proceeding without counsel at that stage.  An accused's waiver is ""knowing and intelligent"" if he is made aware of these basic facts.  Miranda warnings are sufficient for this purpose in the postindictment questioning context
column5: because
column6: at that stage
column7: the role of counsel is relatively simple and limited

column18: FERC entered an order allocating Grand Gulf costs among the members of the MSU system in proportion to their relative demand for energy generated by the system as a whole. column23: the MPSC had exceeded its authority by adopting retail rates to pay Grand Gulf expenses without first determining that the expenses were prudently incurred.  The court agreed and remanded the case

column1: Held:  The FERC proceedings preempted a prudence inquiry by the MPSC.  The decision in Nantahala rests on a foundation that is broad enough to support the order entered by FERC here
column2: and to require the MPSC to treat appellant's FERC-mandated payments for Grand Gulf costs as reasonably incurred operating expenses for the purpose of setting appellant's retail rates.  Nantahala relied on the fundamental preemption principles
column3: applicable here

column5: but also to power allocations that affect wholesale rates; and that States may not bar regulated utilities from passing through to retail consumers FERC-mandated wholesale rates.  The Supremacy Clause compels the MPSC to permit appellant to recover as a reasonable operating expense costs incurred as a result of paying a FERC-determined wholesale rate for a FERC-mandated allocation of power. column11: in fact

column1: An obviously intoxicated off-duty serviceman (Carr) fired several rifle shots into petitioners' automobile on a public street near the Bethesda Naval Hospital where Carr worked
column2: causing physical injury to one of the petitioners and damage to the car.  Petitioners filed suit against the Government under the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) in Federal District Court
column3: alleging that their injuries were caused by the Government's negligence in allowing Carr to leave the hospital with a loaded rifle in his possession.  The facts
column4: as alleged in the complaint and as supplemented by discovery
column5: were that
column6: after finishing his work shift
column7: Carr consumed a large amount of alcoholic beverages; that naval corpsmen found him in a drunken stupor in a hospital building and attempted to take him to the emergency room; that the corpsmen fled when they saw a rifle in his possession; that the corpsmen neither took further action to subdue Carr nor alerted the appropriate authorities that he was intoxicated and brandishing a weapon; and that he fired the shots into petitioners' car later that evening.  The District Court dismissed the action on the ground that the claim was barred by the FTCA's intentional tort exception
column9: which provides that the Act's provisions subjecting the Government to liability for the negligent or wrongful act or omission of a Government employee while acting within the scope of his employment shall not apply to any claim ""arising out of "" an assault or battery.  The court rejected petitioners' argument that  2680(h) was not applicable because they were relying
column10: not on the fact that Carr was a Government employee when he assaulted them
column11: but rather on the negligence of other Government employees who failed to prevent his use of the rifle.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column4: 374 U. S. 150.  Even assuming that
column5: when an intentional tort is a sine qua non of recovery
column6: the action ""arises out of"" that tort
column7: nevertheless the  2680(h) exception does not bar recovery in this case.  The intentional tort exception is inapplicable

Since the FTCA covers actions for personal injuries caused by the negligence or wrongful act or omission of any Government employee ""while acting within the scope of his office or employment

Assuming that petitioners' version of the facts would support recovery under Maryland law on a negligence theory if the naval hospital had been owned and operated by a private person

column8: is also irrelevant.  Pp.  487 U. S. 398-403.

column6: after finishing his work shift

Congress is charged with designing welfare benefits programs
column14: and with balancing the need for administrative efficiency against individual rights
column15: and Congress has discharged that responsibility to the extent that it affects this case.  Pp.  487 U. S. 424-429.

column2: thinly populated school districts are authorized to ""reorganize"" themselves into larger districts so that education can be provided more efficiently.  Reorganization proposals must include provisions for transporting students to and from their homes.  Appellee Dickinson Public Schools
column3: which is relatively populous
column4: has chosen not to participate in such a reorganization.  In 1973
column5: Dickinson's School Board instituted door-to-door bus service and began charging a fee for such transportation.  In 1979
column6: the State enacted a statute authorizing nonreorganized school districts like Dickinson to charge a fee for schoolbus service
column7: not to exceed the district's estimated cost of providing the service.  Appellants are a Dickinson schoolchild (Sarita Kadrmas) and her mother.  In 1985
column8: when the Kadrmas family refused to agree to the busing fee and began transporting Sarita to school privately
column9: appellants filed a state court action seeking to enjoin appellees from collecting any fee for the bus service.  The action was dismissed on the merits
column10: and the Supreme Court of North Dakota affirmed
column11: holding that the 1979 statute does not violate state law or the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  The court rejected appellants' contention that the statute unconstitutionally discriminates on the basis of wealth.  It also rejected the contention that the distinction drawn by the statute between reorganized and nonreorganized school districts violates the Equal Protection Clause.

column9: a State's decision to allow local school boards the option of charging patrons a user fee for bus service is constitutionally permissible.  The Constitution does not require that such service be provided at all

column11: and it is rational for the State to refrain from undermining its objective with a rule requiring that general revenues be used to subsidize an optional service that will benefit a minority of the district's families.  Pp.  487 U. S. 457-462.

column1: (b) The distinction drawn in the 1979 statute between reorganized and nonreorganized school districts does not create an equal protection violation. column7: Florida adopted unisex actuarial tables equalizing benefits under all of the offered plans for similarly situated male and female employees retiring after Norris' effective date.  Respondents

column10: alleging that the optional plans violated Title VII.  The court entered summary judgment for respondents
column11: awarding relief to class members who retired after Manhart's
column14: by retroactively ""topping up"" monthly benefits to the current unisex levels for the period between Manhart and the date of the court's judgment.  Class members were also awarded topped-up future benefits
column15: commencing on the latter date.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column7: inter alia

column1: For the convenience of parties and witnesses

column1: 1. When a federal law sought to be applied in a diversity action is a congressional statute
column2: the chief question for the district court's determination is whether the statute is sufficiently broad to control the issue before the court.  If so
column3: the court then must inquire whether the statute represents a valid exercise of Congress' authority under the Constitution.  If Congress intended to reach the issue before the court
column4: and if it enacted its intention into law in a manner that abides with the Constitution
column5: that is the end of the matter; federal courts are bound to apply laws enacted by Congress with respect to matters over which it has legislative power.  Pp.  487 U. S. 25-27.

column2: federal law
column3: specifically  1404(a)
column4: governs the decision whether to give effect to the parties' forum-selection clause and to transfer the case to a court in Manhattan.  Pp.  487 U. S. 28-32.

column1: (a) Although the Court of Appeals properly noted that the Bremen case -- which held that federal courts sitting in admiralty generally should enforce forum-selection clauses absent a showing that to do so would be unreasonable and unjust
column2: or that the clause was invalid for such reasons as fraud or overreaching -- may prove ""instructive"" in resolving the parties' dispute

column2: case-by-case consideration of convenience and fairness.  A motion to transfer under  1404(a) calls on the district court to weigh in the balance a number of case-specific factors

column4: but rather the consideration for which Congress provided in  1404(a).  Section 1404(a) must be applied
column5: since it represents a valid exercise of Congress' authority under Article III as augmented by the Necessary and Proper Clause.  In this case
column6: the District Court should determine in the first instance the appropriate effect under federal law of the parties' forum-selection clause on respondent's  1404(a) motion.  Pp.  487 U. S. 29-32.

column1: Held:  Virginia's residency requirement for admission to the State's bar without examination violates the Privileges and Immunities Clause.  Pp.  487 U. S. 64-70.

(a) A nonresident's interest in practicing law on terms of substantial equality with those enjoyed by residents is a privilege protected by the Clause.  This Court's precedents do not support appellants' contention that
column2: so long as an applicant has the alternative of gaining admission to a State's bar
column3: without regard to residence
column4: by passing the bar examination
column5: the State has not discriminated against nonresidents ""on a matter of fundamental concern.""  The Clause is implicated whenever a State does not permit qualified nonresidents to practice law within its borders on terms of substantial equality with its own residents.  Cf. Piper
column6: supra.  Appellants' theory that the State could constitutionally require that all bar applicants pass an examination is irrelevant to the question whether the Clause is applicable in the circumstances of this case.  The State has burdened the right to practice law
column7: a privilege protected by the

column2: by discriminating among otherwise equally qualified applicants solely on the basis of citizenship or residency.  Pp.  487 U. S. 65-67.

column1: (b) The State has failed to show that its discrimination against nonresidents bears a close relation to the achievement of substantial state objectives.  Rule 1A:1's residency requirement cannot be justified as assuring
column2: in tandem with the Rule's requirement that the applicant practice full time as a member of the Virginia Bar
column3: that attorneys admitted on motion will have the same commitment to service and familiarity with Virginia law that is possessed by applicants securing admission upon examination.  Lawyers who are admitted in other States and seek admission in Virginia are not less likely to respect the bar and further its interests solely because they are nonresidents.  To the extent that the State is justifiably concerned with ensuring that its attorneys keep abreast of legal developments
column4: it can protect such interest through other equally or more effective means that do not themselves infringe constitutional protections.  Nor can the residency requirement be justified as a necessary aid to the enforcement of Rule 1A:1's full-time practice requirement.  Virginia already requires that attorneys admitted on motion maintain an office in Virginia. column5: rendering the latter restriction largely redundant.  Pp.  487 U. S. 67-70.

column6: entered into a contract for appellee's delivery and installation of a boiler system at appellant's Ohio facility.  After a contract dispute arose

column8: appellant responded that the limitations period had not elapsed
column9: because

column11: the running of the time is tolled for claims against corporations that are not present in the State and have not designated an agent for service of process.  The District Court dismissed the action

column1: Held:  The Ohio tolling statute violates the Commerce Clause
column2: since it imposes an impermissible burden on interstate commerce.  To gain the protection of the limitations period
column3: appellee -- which has no corporate office in Ohio and is not registered to do business there -- would have had to appoint a resident agent for service of process in Ohio and subject itself to the Ohio courts' general jurisdiction.  Ohio's statutory scheme thus forces a foreign corporation to choose between exposure to the general jurisdiction of Ohio courts or forfeiture of the limitations defense
column4: remaining subject to suit in Ohio in perpetuity.  Although statute of limitations defenses are not a fundamental right
column5: they are an integral part of the legal system and are relied upon to project the liabilities of persons and corporations active in the commercial sphere.  Such defenses may not be withdrawn from out-of-state persons or corporations on conditions repugnant to the Commerce Clause.  The ability to execute service of process on foreign corporations is an important factor to consider in assessing the local interest in subjecting out-of-state entities to requirements more onerous than those imposed on domestic parties.  However
column6: Ohio cannot justify its tolling statute as a means of protecting its residents from corporations who become liable for acts done within the State but later withdraw from the jurisdiction
column7: for the parties concede that the Ohio long-arm statute would have permitted service on appellee

column1: throughout the period of limitations.  Moreover
column2: the suggestion that appellee had the simple alternatives of designating an agent for service of process in its contract with appellant or tendering an agency appointment to the Ohio Secretary of State is not persuasive.  Appellant's argument that a finding that the Ohio statute is unconstitutional should be applied prospectively only
column3: and not to the parties in this case
column4: will not be considered by this Court
column5: since the argument was not presented to the courts below.  Pp.  486 U. S. 891-895.

column9: liberty

column1: 1. Title 5 U.S.C.  701(a)(2) precludes judicial review under the APA of the CIA Director's termination decisions under  102(c) of the NSA. Section 701(a)(2) applies where a statute is drawn in such broad terms that

column1: Section 161(v) of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 authorizes the Department of Energy (DOE) to offer its services
column2: for a fee
column3: to convert natural uranium into the enriched uranium used for fuel in commercial reactors
column4: and provides that DOE ""shall"" restrict its enrichment of foreign-source uranium intended for use in domestic facilities ""to the extent necessary to assure the maintenance of a viable domestic uranium industry.""  DOE has determined that the domestic uranium industry has not been ""viable"" since 1983
column5: and that the imposition of restrictions on DOE's enrichment of foreign uranium would not assure viability.  Respondent domestic uranium mining and milling companies filed suit against petitioners (DOE and some of its officers and employees) in Federal District Court
column6: alleging that DOE's failure to impose restrictions on the enrichment of foreign uranium for use in domestic facilities constituted a violation of  161(v).  Respondents moved for summary judgment based on this claim
column7: arguing that two facts -- that the domestic industry was not viable and that DOE imposed no restrictions on enrichment of foreign uranium -- established their entitlement to judgment as a matter of law under  161(v).  Petitioners filed a cross-motion for summary judgment
column8: contending that  161(v) did not require restrictions when those restrictions would not serve the statutory goal of assuring the maintenance of a viable domestic industry.  The court entered summary judgment for respondents
column9: holding that the statute gave DOE no discretion to determine not to impose restrictions if the domestic industry was not viable.  The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment in relevant part.

column1: Held:  Section 161(v) does not require DOE to restrict the enrichment of foreign uranium where such restriction would not achieve the statutory goal of ""assur[ing] the maintenance of a viable domestic uranium industry
column2: for the statute ties the amount of restriction to be imposed to the achievement of that goal.  Pp.  486 U. S. 671-674.
reversed and remanded.

column9: VWAG moved to quash the service on the grounds that it could be served only in accordance with the Hague Service Convention
column10: and that respondent had not complied with the Convention's requirements.  The court denied the motion
column11: reasoning that VWoA and VWAG are so closely related that VWoA is VWAG's agent for service of process as a matter of law

column13: because service was accomplished in this country
column14: the Convention did not apply.  The Appellate Court of Illinois affirmed

column16: and that such service did not violate the Convention.

column1: Held:  The Hague Service Convention does not apply when process is served on a foreign corporation by serving its domestic subsidiary which
column2: under state law
column3: is the foreign corporation's involuntary agent for service.  Pp.  486 U. S. 698-708.

column1: (a) The service of process in this case is not covered by Article I of the Convention
column2: which provides that the Convention ""shall apply . . . where there is occasion to transmit a judicial . . . document for service abroad.""  ""Service"" means a formal delivery of documents that is legally sufficient to charge the defendant with notice of a pending action.  Since the Convention does not itself prescribe a standard for determining the legal sufficiency of the delivery
column3: the internal law of the forum state controls.  Thus
column4: where
column5: as here
column6: the forum state's law does not define the applicable method of serving process as requiring the transmittal of documents

column2: the Convention does not apply.  This interpretation is consistent with the negotiating history and the general purposes of the Convention.  One purpose of the Convention is to provide means to facilitate service of process abroad.  The Convention implements this purpose by requiring each state to establish a central authority to assist in the service of process
column3: and nothing in the present decision interferes with that requirement.  Another purpose of the Convention is to assure foreign defendants adequate notice.  The present decision does not necessarily advance this purpose
column4: because it makes application of the Convention depend on the forum's internal law; however
column5: it is unlikely that any country will draft its internal laws deliberately so as to circumvent the Convention in cases in which it would be appropriate to transmit judicial documents for service abroad.  Furthermore
column6: this decision does not prevent voluntary compliance with the Convention even when the forum's internal law does not so require
column7: and such compliance can be advantageous.  Pp.  486 U. S. 698-706.

column1: (b) VWAG's contention that service upon it was not complete until VWoA transmitted the complaint to it in Germany
column2: and that this transmission ""for service abroad"" rendered the Convention applicable to the case under Article I
column3: is without merit.  Where
column4: as here
column5: service on a domestic agent is valid and complete under both state law and the Due Process Clause without an official transmission of documents abroad
column6: the inquiry ends and the Convention has no further implications.  Pp.  486 U. S. 706-708.

column1: Held:  Noerr antitrust immunity does not apply to petitioner.

column2: context
column3: and nature of the anticompetitive restraint at issue.  Where a restraint is the result of valid governmental action
column4: as opposed to private action

column1: those urging the governmental action enjoy absolute immunity from antitrust liability for the anticompetitive restraint.  In this case
column2: the relevant context is the standard-setting process of a private association without official authority that includes members having horizontal and vertical business relations and economic incentives to restrain competition.  Such an association cannot be treated as a ""quasi-legislative"" body simply because legislatures routinely adopt its Code
column3: and thus petitioner does not enjoy the immunity afforded those who merely urge the government to restrain trade.  Pp.  486 U. S. 499-502.

column8: regardless of the Association's nonlegislative status
column9: petitioner's efforts to influence the Association must be given the same wide berth accorded legislative lobbying or efforts to influence legislative action in the political arena.  Pp.  486 U. S. 502-504.

column1: (c) Unlike the publicity campaign to influence legislation in Noerr
column2: petitioner's activity did not take place in the open political arena
column3: where partisanship is the hallmark of decisionmaking
column4: but took place within the confines of a private standard-setting process.  The validity of petitioner's efforts to influence the Code is not established

column6: by petitioner's literal compliance with the Association's rules
column7: for the hope of the Code's procompetitive benefits depends upon the existence of safeguards sufficient to prevent the standard-setting process from being biased by members with economic interests in restraining competition.  An association cannot validate the anticompetitive activities of its members simply by adopting rules that fail to provide such safeguards.  At least where

column10: that party enjoys no Noerr immunity from any antitrust liability flowing from the effect the standard has of its own force in the marketplace.  Pp.  486 U. S. 505-510.

column1: A provision of the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) excepts from statutory liability any claim
based upon [a federal agency's or employee's] exercise or performance or the failure to exercise or perform a discretionary function or duty.""
Upon contracting a severe case of polio after ingesting a dose of Orimune
column2: an oral polio vaccine manufactured by Lederle Laboratories
column3: petitioner Kevan Berkovitz
column4: a minor
column5: joined by his parents (also petitioners) as guardians
column6: filed an FTCA suit alleging violations of federal law and policy by the National Institutes of Health's Division of Biologic Standards (DBS) in licensing Lederle to produce Orimune
column7: and by the Bureau of Biologics of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in approving the release to the public of the particular lot of vaccine containing Berkovitz's dose.  The District Court denied the Government's motion to dismiss the suit for lack of subject matter jurisdiction
column8: but the Court of Appeals reversed.  Although rejecting the Government's argument that the discretionary function exception bars all claims arising out of federal agencies' regulatory activities
column9: the court held that the licensing and release of polio vaccines are wholly discretionary actions protected by the exception.

column2: purpose
column3: and legislative history of the discretionary function exception
column4: as well as its interpretation in this Court's decisions
column5: establish that the exception does not preclude liability for any and all acts arising out of federal agencies' regulatory programs
column6: but insulates from liability only those governmental actions and decisions that involve an element of judgment or choice and that are based on public policy considerations.  Pp.  486 U. S. 535-539.

column1: 2. The Court of Appeals erred in holding that the discretionary function exception bars petitioners' claims.  Pp.  486 U. S. 539-548.
(a) Statutory and regulatory provisions require the DBS
column2: prior to issuing a license for a product such as Orimune
column3: to receive all data which the manufacturer is required to submit
column4: to examine the product
column5: and to make a determination that it complies with safety standards.  Thus
column6: a cause of action based on petitioner's allegation that the DBS licensed Orimune without first receiving the required safety data is not barred by the discretionary function exception
column7: since the DBS has no discretion to

column1: issue a license under such circumstances
column2: and doing so would violate a specific statutory and regulatory directive.  Petitioners' other claim -- that the DBS licensed Orimune even though the vaccine did not comply with certain regulatory safety standards -- if interpreted to mean that the DBS issued the license without determining compliance with the standards or after determining a failure to comply
column3: also is not barred by the discretionary function exception
column4: since the claim charges the agency with failing to act in accordance with specific mandatory directives
column5: as to which the DBS has no discretion.  However
column6: if this claim is interpreted to mean that the DBS made an incorrect compliance determination
column7: the question of the discretionary function exception's applicability turns on whether the DBS officials making that determination permissibly exercise policy choice
column8: a point that is not clear from the record and therefore must be decided by the District Court if petitioners choose to press this interpretation.  Pp.  486 U. S. 540-545.

column1: (b) Although the regulatory scheme governing the public release of vaccine lots allows the FDA to determine the appropriate manner in which to regulate
column2: petitioners have alleged that
column3: under the authority granted by the regulations
column4: the FDA has adopted a policy of testing all lots for compliance with safety standards and of preventing the public distribution of any lot that fails to comply
column5: and that
column6: notwithstanding this mandatory policy
column7: the FDA knowingly approved the release of the unsafe lot in question.  Accepting these allegations as true
column8: as is necessary in reviewing a dismissal
column9: the holding that the discretionary function exception barred petitioners' claim was improper
column10: since the acts complained of do not involve the permissible exercise of discretion to release a noncomplying lot on the basis of policy considerations.  Pp.  486 U. S. 545-548.

column2: reversed and remanded.

column1: Petitioner was discharged from his position with the United States Postal Service.  Contending that his discharge resulted from sex discrimination
column2: petitioner brought this suit against the Postmaster General in Federal District Court pursuant to  717 of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.  The court found for petitioner and ordered his reinstatement with backpay
column3: but refused to award prejudgment interest.  The Court of Appeals affirmed the denial of prejudgment interest.  Relying in part on Library of Congress v. Shaw
column5: which held that sovereign immunity barred the payment of interest on attorney's fees awarded against the Library of Congress under Title VII
column6: the court concluded that Congress had not waived the Postal Service's sovereign immunity as to prejudgment interest in a Title VII suit
column7: even though Congress had provided in the 1970 Postal Reorganization Act
column9: that the Postal Service may ""sue and be sued.""

column1: Held:  Prejudgment interest may be awarded in a suit against the Postal Service brought under Title VII.  Pp.  486 U. S. 554-565.
(a) By launching the Service into the commercial world and including a sue-and-be-sued clause in the Postal Reorganization Act
column2: Congress removed the Service's cloak of sovereignty and gave it the status of a private commercial enterprise.  The clause must be liberally construed
column3: and the Service's liability must be presumed to be the same as that of any other business.  Thus
column4: Congress is presumed to have waived any otherwise existing immunity of the Service from interest awards.  None of the exceptions to the liberal construction rule operate to overcome this presumption.  Franchise Tax Board of California v. USPS

column1: (b) Since Title VII authorizes interest awards as a normal incident of suits against private parties
column2: and since Congress
column3: by enacting the sue-and-be-sued clause in the Postal Reorganization Act
column4: has waived the Service's immunity from such awards
column5: respondent may be subjected to an interest award in this case.  Pp.  486 U. S. 557-558.

column1: (c) There is no merit to respondent's contention that the waiver of sovereign immunity effected by the sue-and-be-sued clause has no force in this case.  The history of the Postal Reorganization Act
column2: with its emphasis

column1: on the availability of strong remedies for discrimination in the federal employment context
column2: makes clear that Congress' failure to extend Title VII protections to Postal Service employees did not reflect an intent to circumscribe the waiver of sovereign immunity effected by the sue-and-be-sued clause
column3: but
column4: rather
column5: was a determination that a Title VII cause of action was unnecessary in light of such alternative remedies.  Nor is the sue-and-be-sued clause irrelevant merely because
column6: when Congress extended a Title VII cause of action to federal employees in 1972
column7: it included special procedures and limitations applicable only in actions against federal defendants.  Neither the language of  717 nor its legislative history indicates that the waiver of sovereign immunity it effected was intended to narrow the waiver of sovereign immunity of entities subject to sue-and-be-sued clauses.  Pp.  486 U. S. 560-562.
